pages.content:
[HEADING] Master Atmospheric and Climate Science
[HEADING] Language of instruction
[HEADING] Credits | duration
[HEADING] Academic title
[HEADING] Requirement profile
[HEADING] Detailed information
[HEADING] Contact
This specialized Master's degree programme is offered by the Institute for Atmospheric and Climate Science of the Department of Environmental Systems Sciences and the Department of Earth and Planetary Sciences.
Students in this Master gain detailed knowledge in climate processes and feedbacks- ranging from the molecular to the global scale and from short-lived phenomena to changes in millions of years.
Students can choose 3 out of the following fields:
Elective courses can be used to either deepen the knowledge in one of the above mentioned fields or to broaden the knowledge in the field of atmospheric and climate sciences.
Practical courses give insight into lab and field work as well as in numerical modelling also in the field of high performance computing. During the Master's thesis, students work on their own research project for 6 months which is embedded in one of the research groups at the Institute for Atmospheric and Climate Science.
This Master is suitable for BSc students with a profound knowledge in Mathematics, Physics and Chemistry (e.g. BSc in Earth and Climate Sciences, BSc in Physics, BSc in Chemistry) or also to students with a BSc in Geography when they obtained additional knowledge in Mathematics/Physics/Chemistry.
90 ECTS | 1.5 years
Master of Science ETH in Atmospheric and Climate Science
Download MSc Atmospheric and Climate Science (PDF, 227 KB)
Master’s degree programme in Atmospheric and Climate Science

pages.title: Master Atmospheric and Climate Science | ETH Zurich

pages.content:
[HEADING] MSc Students
[HEADING] Curriculum
[HEADING] Differences between the two curricula
[HEADING] Additional Information
[HEADING] Contact
The Institute for Atmospheric and Climate Science offers two Master programmes. The MSc in Atmospheric and Climate Science, hosted by the Department of Earth and Planetary Sciences and the MSc in Environmental Science, Major Atmosphere and Climate, hosted by the Department of Environmental Systems Science. Both programmes are very similar, the students attend the same courses and follow a very similar curriculum. However, there are subtle differences between the two programmes.
The following information applies to the Master in Atmospheric and Climate Science and the Master in Environmental Sciences, Major Atmosphere and Climate.
This is an example structure of the Master programme. Note that students in the Environmental Sciences Master programme must complete an internship but are free to choose at what time during their studies they decide to do the internship.
For more details consult the Study Guides and Programme Regulations for the Master in Atmospheric and Climate Sciences at the Department of Earth and Planetary Sciences or for the Master in Environmetnal Sciences with Major Atmosphere and Climate at the Department for Environmental Systems Science:
Institut für Atmosphäre und Klima

                8092

pages.title: MSc Students – Institute for Atmospheric and Climate Science | ETH Zurich

pages.content:
[HEADING] Master’s degree studies
[HEADING] Personal initiative and cross-disciplinary competences
[HEADING] Contact
[HEADING] FAQ Master
[HEADING] Application
[HEADING] Master’s studies
[HEADING] Telephone hours
[HEADING] Desk opening hours
Is it your goal to do cutting-edge research, start your own company or pursue a career in business, industry or administration? A Master’s degree from ETH Zurich would be the ideal stepping stone to your future.
ETH Zurich is one of the world’s leading technical and scientific universities. With members from over 100 nations, we offer our students an inspiring, diverse environment.
During your studies you will have the chance to interact with top researchers, address the latest scientific knowledge in your field and apply it in practice.
Take advantage of the range of selections offered in our curricula and shape your studies according to your personal strengths and interests. We count on your personal initiative, and will help you to develop your own projects. Besides imparting knowledge and skills for your future career we will prepare you for the responsibilities you will assume in society as a graduate. For this reason, we lay great weight on the development of cross-disciplinary competences such as critical reflection and argumentation.
The prerequisites for undertaking graduate studies at ETH Zurich are a Bachelor’s degree from an internationally recognised university and excellent grades. Our students immerse themselves independently and enthusiastically in their chosen fields, pursue discussion with peers and faculty, and value cultural and academic diversity.
Please understand that we cannot provide academic guidance in advance or assess your chances of admission.
Frequently asked questions on Master's degree studies and application
If you have questions about applying for Master’s degree studies (formal admission prerequisites, application process), which are not  answered in the FAQ section, please contact the Admissions Office.
If you have questions on the content of a degree programme, please contact the person responsible for the respective programme directly .
ETH Zurich

pages.title: Master’s degree studies | ETH Zurich

pages.content:
[HEADING] Range of degree programmes
[HEADING] Structure of Master’s degree studies
[HEADING] Consecutive Master’s degree programmes
[HEADING] Specialised Master’s degree programmes
During Master’s degree studies you will deepen your knowledge of your chosen academic discipline and specialise in one or more of its aspects. ETH Zurich offers both consecutive and specialised Master’s degree programmes.
In their content, consecutive Master’s degree programmes represent a continu­ation of the respective Bachelor’s degree pro­gramme. For every Bachelor’s pro­gramme we offer at least one consecutive Master’s programme.
Specialised Master’s degree programmes address one particular topic, which is taught from an interdisciplinary and international perspective.
